He was taken to Mater Dei Hospital for observation, but it was later confirmed that he was not injured.Four women, aged 39, 66, 77 and 84, and two men aged 36 and 81, all residing in Zabbar, were taken to Mater Dei Hospital by ambulances. A motorcyclist was rushed to hospital in a critical condition after he smashed into a stationary garbage skip on the St Paul's Bay bypass on Wednesday afternoon. The incident was reported to the police at around 5pm.  A police spokesperson said the man - a 54-year-old English man from Mellieħa - suffered serious injuries and was rushed to Mater Dei Hospital. According to the police, the man lost control of his Honda and crashed into a stationary skip on the bypass.

A private contractor who placed a skip on St Paul's Bay bypass that was involved in a serious road accident on Wednesday did not have a permit, local authorities say.  The mayor of St Paul’s Bay, Infrastructure Malta, and Transport Malta all said they did not grant permission for the unnamed contractor to place a skip on the road on Wednesday.  A 54-year-old motorcyclist was seriously injured when he crashed into the stationary garbage skip left on a blind bend along the bypass.  Transport Malta said it "was not informed about the works, and the contractor did not hold a valid permit to carry out works at the site where the accident occurred."  Similarly, Infrastructure Malta said it "had not been notified about the works, and no permission was requested for them." However, it acknowledged that the accident occurred near works being carried out by a private contractor under its administration. It did not name the contractor involved. In October, Infrastructure Malta began work to replace a dangerous leaning wall along the same bypass section where the accident happened. St Paul’s Bay Mayor, Censu Galea, also confirmed that the council had not issued any permits. "No permits were ever issued as far as I am informed," he said. He said he was told the skip was placed on the road at around 1pm on Wednesday. The incident was reported to the police at around 5pm.  The mayor noted that the same skip had been in the same location two to three months ago, and people raised safety concerns with the council at the time. He explained that once he was informed, the council alerted Infrastructure Malta, which added cones and bollards at that time. The skip involved in Wednesday’s accident was left at the final curve leading to the Xemxija roundabout. According to the police, the injured motorcyclist, an English man from Mellieħa, lost control of his Honda and collided with the skip. He remains in Mater Dei Hospital with serious injuries. While traffic cones and a bollard were at the site, an eyewitness and social media users described these safety features as insufficient.

Those who wish to give blood and have any queries should phone 8007 4313 to check if they are eligible. Donors should take their identity card, driving licence or Maltese passport with them. content: Updated: 3.30pm A truck driver was grievously injured when his vehicle overturned, spilling an entire load of construction sand across the road near Mdina on Friday morning. The accident happened on Triq Buqana in Rabat at around 10am. The spillage caused both carriageways of the main road leading to Mġarr to be closed to traffic. The driver of the DAC truck - a 35-year-old man from Marsascala - was taken to hospital by ambulance.  In a Facebook post, Transport Malta announced it had closed the road in both directions until the vehicle and the sand were cleared away.  ROTA urges segregation of high-speed traffic, bicycles  In a statement on Friday afternoon, bicycle advocacy group ROTA said the crash flagged the urgent need for better road safety measures, particularly for bicycle users. The truck, the NGO said, ended up within the bicycle lane, where, had there been a bicycle user, they could have been fatally injured. "The current road design offers no protection for cyclists, and this tragic event highlights the pressing need for proper segregation between high-speed traffic and vulnerable road users, particularly those on bicycles," ROTA said. The need for protected bicycle lanes is not just a local issue - the matter has also been flagged in international road safety guidelines such as the CROW guidelines. These guidelines emphasise the importance of segregation in high-speed areas and the need for roads that are forgiving of human error, the group noted. "In simple terms, we must ensure that the consequences of mistakes – whether made by a driver or a cyclist – are not fatal. Sadly, Malta is still without a legally binding national cycling policy that will outline clear standards for the design and implementation of safe and effective bicycle lanes. "We cannot allow cyclists to be subjected to what is, at best, a makeshift effort that often amounts to nothing more than a splash of green paint and some rumble strips. It is not enough. Bicycle lanes need to be designed to protect cyclists – physically separated from traffic in high-speed areas, with sufficient space and barriers to prevent accidents."

content: The wife of the motorcyclist who died on the Xemxija bypass on Tuesday has shared a heartfelt goodbye message in which she promised to keep his memory alive for the young daughter he had “so many dreams and plans for”.  In a post shared on Facebook, Stef Coppola, the wife of 35-year-old Shaun Coppola, who died in the accident, wrote: “I called you and you did not reply. I looked, but I couldn’t believe it. I have so much to tell you, but I’m speechless. I know you’re not coming back but I hope that they tell us they made a mistake," she posted on Facebook, alongside an image of the couple with their young daughter.  "I know it’s not a dream, but I feel it is…. I love you forever, I promise I will keep your memory alive for our darling, for who you had so many dreams and plans… [We] are forever proud of you.” Shaun Coppola, from Qormi, died on impact on Tuesday afternoon after he lost control of his Suzuki motorcycle at around 12.30 pm. A 16-year-old boy from Mtarfa is in critical condition following a bicycle accident that occurred around 12:30 p.m. yesterday on Triq il-Buqana, Rabat.

A scooter rider injured in a hit-and-run crash in the Regional Road tunnels earlier this month is struggling to track down the driver, after being told that none of the tunnel cameras work. Giuseppe Di Dio, a 22-year-old Sicilian who works as a DJ and event organiser, was riding his Vespa 300 on July 2 at around 12.30pm when he was hit. As he entered the tunnel heading towards Swieqi, he says a van crossed into his lane, cut him off and crashed into him, knocking him off his Vespa. “I feel super lucky to tell the story. It hurt a lot. When I was on the floor, I could feel my burns,” he told Times of Malta. Shocked by the impact, Di Dio said he could not identify the van but recalled opening his eyes to see the driver standing over him. According to Di Dio, the man looked South Asian and was wearing a blue shirt. He believes he was driving a delivery van but is unsure which company the van belonged to. “He came over, checked I was alive, told me nothing and rushed off,” he said. “I know if I saw him, I would recognise him.” Thankfully, other drivers stopped to help Di Dio. He was taken to Mater Dei Hospital, where he said he had to wait between six to seven hours before being seen. “That was horrible. I couldn’t take it anymore and began to scream out in pain, and only then did they see me,” he said. He was initially told he had minor injuries and was prescribed painkillers. But after several days, his wounds became increasingly painful and doctors at Saint James Hospital later confirmed they were infected. Alongside the physical injuries, Di Dio said his motorbike was damaged and he incurred around €4,000 in expenses for medical treatment, medications, transport and missed work. “I want a refund for the damages but the most important thing is I want to find out who hit me to avoid future accidents,” he said.  After being treated, Di Dio filed a police report. He hoped CCTV footage from the tunnel would help identify the van. But he said police informed him that the security cameras inside the Ta’ Giorni tunnels do not work. “It’s insane. The policeman told me that none of the cameras they have for the tunnels work,” he said. “I told them that it is impossible but they told me again that none of them work.” In 2020, the government launched a €10 million project to upgrade Malta’s major tunnels, including Ta’ Giorni, which included the installation of security cameras. When asked if the cameras were working on the day of the incident, the transport ministry said: “The Traffic Control Centre did not have CCTV coverage in the mentioned area on the 2nd of July 2025.” The ministry did not answer questions about whether the cameras are operational. Police confirmed that a report on the accident had been filed and investigations are ongoing. In 2022, a Transport Malta spokesperson told Times of Malta that tunnel cameras were linked to the authority’s traffic control centre, and used for both congestion monitoring and automatic incident detection.

You will be sorely missed…. I love you to death my dearest sister. Look after your children, your husband and your little grandchildren,” her sister wrote. The woman had been fishing shortly before the accident on Sunday at 10pm.   She was the third person to die on the roads in three separate accidents on Sunday. Earlier that evening, at about 7.30pm, in Marina Street, Pieta’ a 58-year-old man from Żejtun lost control of his Honda motorcycle, crashed into a pavement and fell off. He died soon after. In the afternoon, a 71-year-old woman died and another is in a critical condition following a two-car crash involving Robert Abela's mother and father – former president George Abela and Margaret Abela. The crash happened at around 3.30pm on Triq Hompesh, the busy Fgura road leading to Żabbar. A 23-year-old woman from Żabbar who was driving the vehicle is in a critical condition. Prime Minister Robert Abela later said his parents were in a stable condition in hospital.

content: A 63-year-old man from Naxxar has died after being hit by a bus at the Floriana Park and Ride facility.  The accident happened at around 1.45 pm on Tuesday. He was taken to Mater Dei Hospital by ambulance, where he was being treated for serious injuries, police said. He was later pronounced dead. It is the fifth fatal accident on Malta's roads in just four days.  On Saturday, a 27-year-old motorcyclist was killed when his bike was involved in a crash with a BMW in Pembroke in the early hours of the morning.  The following day a woman died in a head-on crash in Fgura that also involved former president George Abela and his wife. A motorcyclist died in Pieta a few hours later.  And on Sunday evening  mother of four, Mildred Azzopardi, died when she was trapped between two cars in a crash on Sunday evening. A 23-year-old soldier has been charged with involuntary homicide for Azzopardi's death.

The son of former Malta footballer Alfred Azzopardi says he is fighting for his life after a car crash that killed his wife on Sunday.  Cain Azzopardi paid a heartbreaking tribute to his mother, Mildred, who was crushed to death when a Subaru Imprezza crashed into the parked family car. The driver of the Subaru Impreza, 23-year-old soldier Benjamin Chetcuti, has been charged with involuntary homicide and drink-driving. He denies all charges. "You didn't deserve this ma after someone irresponsible took your life, we miss you so much and we keep pushing forward as dad keeps fighting for his life," Cain Azzopardi wrote on Facebook on Wednesday. "My best friend, we won't be visiting the Pyramids in Egypt together like we always wanted to. But I know you will there with me. I love you ❤️"  Another of the victim's four children, Amy Azzopardi, shared details of her funeral, which will be held at 9.15am on Saturday at the Floriana Saint Publius Church.  She asked mourners not to wear black, but instead dress in colour "preferably turquoise or orange her favourite colours". The couple had finished a fishing trip at the Valletta waterfront when the crash happened at Ta' Liesse in Valletta. Mildred Azzopardi, 62, was outside the parked Ford Fiesta while her husband Alfred Azzopardi, 69, was inside.  Alfred Azzopardi is a popular figure in Ħamrun, given his successful career as a football player with Ħamrun Spartans during their golden years in the 1980s. He played as a defender, spending over 10 years with the Spartans, helping the Reds to Premier League promotion in season 1975-76. His best years with the Spartans arrived in the 1980s as he helped his club to a league and cup double in season 1982-83 and the FA Trophy the following campaign. In season 1985-86, he helped the Reds to lift the Euro Cup. During his career, Azzopardi also donned the colours of Hibernians and was selected to represent the Malta national team, where he collected eight international caps.

The emergency services were called to assist 1,000 people over five days with cases ranging from fatal and life-threatening accidents to people who consumed too much alcohol, emergency doctor Michael Spiteri has said. Speaking on TVM news, Spiteri noted that between Thursday and Monday, the emergency ambulance service attended over 200 cases daily. “Half of the 1,000 calls for assistance included people with serious problems [who did not need immediate medical assistance for survival], and 10% of them were in a critical situation in which, a few minutes could make a difference between life and death”, he said. Spiteri appealed to people who happened to be passing near an accident, to keep away from the site in order not to disrupt the emergency doctors. He called for more sensitivity and for people not to film or photograph accidents, saying this caused psychological damage to patients and their relatives. Over the past days, there were five fatalities on the road. On Saturday, a 27-year-old motorcyclist — Bulgarian Tenyo Kosev — was killed when his bike was involved in a crash with a BMW in Pembroke in the early hours of the morning. The following day, a woman died in a head-on crash in Fgura that also involved former president George Abela and his wife. A motorcyclist died in Pietà a few hours later. And on Sunday, evening mother-of-four, Mildred Azzopardi, died when she was trapped between two cars in a crash. A 23-year-old soldier has been charged with involuntary homicide for her death. On Tuesday, 63-year-old Tallinja driving instructor Karmenu Muscat, died after a bus rolled back on him at the Floriana Park and Ride facility at around 1.45 pm.

content: Six people were killed between July 23 and 29, marking the deadliest week on Malta’s roads in at least 25 years, a toll that one expert says is a result of chronic failure to prioritise safety in road design. Data compiled by transport activist Paolo Cassar Manghi shows that no other seven-day period since at least 2000 has recorded so many road deaths. Cassar Manghi, a transport researcher and road safety advocate, described the spike in fatalities as “tragic but not surprising”, warning that the country’s road infrastructure often encourages speed rather than discouraging risk. Among the six victims were a driving instructor crushed by a runaway bus, a motorcyclist and a pedestrian killed in a crash involving a parked car. On the same week, three others were killed in unrelated violent incidents, in one of the bloodiest weeks in Malta on record. On July 23, a 79-year-old woman from Mosta died after the Renault van she was a passenger in crashed with a Suzuki Swift car in Lija. Three days later, Tenyo Kosev died when his Honda motorcycle was involved in a collision with a BMW 1 Series motorcycle in Pembroke at around 1am. Last Sunday, three people died. Mildred Azzopardi was crushed to death after a vehicle ploughed into a parked car, fatally hitting the 62-year-old. Azzopardi’s husband, Alfred, was critically injured. Benjamin Chetcuti, who was driving the car that hit the Azzopardis, is facing charges of manslaughter and driving under the influence of alcohol. The other two victims were a motorcyclist and a car passenger who was involved in a collision with a car driven by former president George Abela with his wife Margaret in the passenger seat.  Transport Minister Chris Bonett, however, has insisted that the police unit is not a replacement for the bureau and the two bodies will work together. “Two types of investigation are carried out: to establish what led to an accident, and second, to see what happens next... the idea is to work together,” he said in June. Bonett later clarified that the bureau’s main task will be to analyse how to make roads safer and recommend changes. A terrible week made worse by double murder, death after hotel brawl The bloodbath in Malta was exacerbated with the murder of two men and another who died following a fight. Two men – Anthony Agius and Dennis Mifsud – were shot dead in the Kunċizzjoni area of Baħrija. Seventy-two-year-old Carmelo Ciantar has been arrested over the crime. Separately, Roderick Sciortino died on Thursday following a hotel brawl in Mellieħa. His death remains under investigation, with conflicting reports over whether a pre-existing brain tumour contributed to his collapse.

content: Former president George Abela and his wife Margaret, who suffered serious injuries following a traffic accident a week ago, have been discharged from hospital. The couple, who are also the parents of Prime Minister Robert Abela, were discharged late last week and are now “recovering slowly at home”, a spokesperson for the Department of Information said. They were amongst others injured in a head-on collision between a Toyota Corolla and an Audi Q3 on July 27 at 3.30 pm on Triq Hompesh, the busy Fgura road leading to Żabbar. A 71-year-old woman from Żabbar involved in the collision was pronounced dead shortly after the incident. Her 23-year-old daughter was also in a critical condition but has since been discharged. Besides George and Margaret Abela, three others were in the Audi: a 42-year-old woman and two boys aged 14 and 11. George Abela, 77, served as president of Malta from 2009 to 2014. Before that he was a senior figure in the Labour Party, serving for a time as deputy leader. He was also a candidate for the role of party leader in 2008. The week between July 23 and 29 was the deadliest week on Malta’s roads in at least 25 years, with multiple fatalities reported.

content: A fundraiser for a food courier killed in a hit-and-run on Sunday has raised over €11,000 in less than 24 hours. Khim Bahadur Pun, 42, from Nepal, was carrying his Wolt delivery bag when his motorcycle was hit in  Birkirkara at 5.25am. An underage driver, who was arrested after fleeing the scene, is to be arraigned on Monday in connection with the crash.  The Non-Resident Nepali Association (NRNA) said there had been "huge support" for a fundraiser it set up to help the father-of-three's family and to cover the funeral costs in Nepal.   Khanal described the Nepalese community as "one big family", and said the loss of Pun had deeply affected them all. He said he was deeply moved and grateful to see such "overwhelming" support for Pun. "This generosity not only reflects the kindness and compassion of people here in Malta and beyond, but also gives strength and hope to Khim's family during this incredibly difficult time. It's a powerful reminder that humanity transcends borders, and when we come together, we can truly make a difference." A 17-year-old from Qormi, is due to be taken to court on Monday afternoon.  The motorist was driving his father's Maserati Levante when the crash happened at 5.20am in Psaila Street, Sta Venera. He was arrested several hours later, along with an 18-year-old passenger who also ran away from the scene.  A third passenger, an 18-year-old woman also from Qormi, was arrested minutes after the crash, close to the scene of the crash, having suffered injuries.

content: The sister of the food courier killed in a hit-and-run on Sunday said his family depends on him to cover everyday expenses, and, now, they are concerned about how the young family will cope. “He would send money every month to cover the children’s fees, school bills, housing bills, everything,” his sister, Nardevi Pun said. “His three children and wife depend on him. Now we are worried how his young family will cope.” Khim Bahadur Pun, 42, from Nepal, was carrying his Wolt delivery bag when his motorcycle was hit by a Maserati car in Birkirkara at 5.25am on Sunday. A 17-year-old driver, who was arrested after fleeing the scene yesterday pleaded not guilty to causing his death and to driving under the influence. Nardevi, 39, who lives in Nepal, said the family are deeply upset and shocked by her brother’s death. Holding back tears, she said the last time she spoke to her older brother was the day before the fatal accident, on Saturday, when the two chatted briefly. “He told me he was coming back to Nepal very soon. He told me that, after three or four months, he would be back,” she said. The middle child of three siblings, Khim moved to Malta over three years ago to work as a courier. His younger sister said their parents are devastated by the news of his death, grieving at the loss of their youngest son. “It was completely unexpected and they are overcome by sadness,” she said. 'Anger and frustration' She described how the family was filled with “anger and frustration” over the loss of Khim, who she described as a “vibrant soul” taken away too soon.  “The circumstances surrounding Khim’s death are unacceptable. This was not an accident; it was a reckless act that resulted in the loss of a precious life. We demand justice for Khim,” she said, highlighting how the driver must be held accountable for their actions. She said Khim’s wife was informed about her husband’s death by his brother’s wife. “She fainted when told and has not stopped crying since,” Nardevi said. She said Khim’s eldest son, who is 14, knows about his father’s death. His younger son, eight, and his six-year-old daughter still do not know. Khim’s sister described him as an honest and hard-working man. “He was a good person and always looked out for others in our community. He was always ready to help someone in need,” she explained. “My family and I are so sad and upset as we lost a huge pillar of our family.” When the family found out the circumstances around Khim’s death, she said the family began to question law and order in Malta. “We want justice for Khim and his family. His family need support and must be kept informed about the case.” €16,000 raised to repatriate the body, help the family Pun’s body will be repatriated on Wednesday a final farewell will be organised by members of the Nepali community outside Mater Dei Hospital at  9am. A vigil for Pun was held by Nepalese nationals near the crash site on Sunday evening, when they lit candles and prayed. A fundraiser organised by the Non-Resident Nepali Association (NRNA) had raised over €16,000 by Monday afternoon to help his family and cover the funeral costs in Nepal. “Seeing this huge support towards the GoFundMe page for Khim shows the kindness and solidarity not only within our own Nepali community but also from the Maltese and other friends around us,” NRNA president, Rems Khanal said.

A man accused of murdering a driver after a minor road collision has been charged with a second alleged road rage incident that took place months before the fatal shooting. Mohamed Hamdan, 46, appeared in court yesterday to face a string of driving offences  over a January incident in St Paul’s Bay, in which he allegedly rammed his truck into a car following a traffic dispute. The incident, caught on camera and exclusively revealed by Times of Malta, involved Hamdan allegedly attempting to park his truck to make a water delivery to a hotel. Police inspector Warren Galea told the court that the alleged victim, driving a red Mazda, had overtaken Hamdan and blocked his access to the designated delivery spot on Triq it-Turisti.   The two men exited their vehicles and initially exchanged words. The situation quickly escalated, and a passenger had to intervene to separate them. Hamdan then returned to his truck and drove into the Mazda, which was later declared a total loss. Three other parked vehicles were also extensively damaged. The court heard that the accused was arrested at the time but released on police bail until February 26, pending the submission of medical documentation by the alleged victim. Despite repeated visits by Hamdan to the Qawra police station to seek updates, the requested documents were not submitted until March. The alleged victim presented a medical certificate and vehicle damage valuation report, both dated January. Hamdan also sustained a scratch, which was certified as slight injuries. Hamdan was called back to the police station on April 15. He requested to have his lawyer, Nicholas Mifsud, present before any interrogation. However, inspector Galea explained that due to Mifsud’s involvement in a high-profile jury case, the interview was postponed. Before a new date could be set, the fatal Bidnija shooting occurred. Hamdan was arrested and charged with murdering Jean Paul Busuttil in yet another traffic dispute. Given the circumstances, police decided to file the earlier road rage charges on July 4 without conducting a formal interrogation. Hamdan pleaded not guilty to wilful damage to a car, slightly injuring the driver, damaging three parked cars through negligent and reckless driving, dangerous driving and recidivism. The alleged victim took the stand yesterday. Cautioned that he could face charges himself, the man chose to testify. He said he had been collecting employees from the Buġibba Hotel at around 6.30am when Hamdan’s truck reversed towards him. He claimed he tried to manoeuvre around the truck, asking Hamdan to let him pass so the latter could park. The witness described Hamdan exiting the truck and allegedly swearing and trying to punch him. He said his employees stepped in to defuse the situation, and as he returned to close the back passenger door, Hamdan drove his truck into his car and then several others. Under cross-examination, the alleged victim admitted that his car was in the middle of the road but insisted he had no alternative route to where he was going. He denied pushing Hamdan but admitted to “blocking” him when the accused attempted to strike him. Lawyer Jacob Magri, representing the alleged victim as parte civile, requested a protection order following the testimony. The court, presided over by Magistrate Leonard Caruana, is expected to rule on the matter from chambers. The case continues in October. Police inspector Warren Galea prosecuted. Lawyer Nicholas Mifsud assisted Hamdan. Lawyers Arthur Azzopardi and Jacob Magri are assisting alleged victim.

Police said the man was “aggressive towards the police” during his arrest, though no officers were injured. Both riders were taken to Gozo General Hospital for treatment. The British man’s condition remains pending. Police investigations are ongoing.

Four Maltese people – two men and two women – were killed in a tragic road accident in Croatia when their car veered off the road and into the sea. The accident happened at around 4.20pm on Thursday, on the D8 state road near Bunica, just south of Senj. The car was travelling from Rijeka towards Senj when the driver lost control in a left bend. The vehicle veered to the right, struck two stone barriers, plunged around 70 metres down a ravine, and ended up in the sea, according to Croatia Week.   “Reports also indicate there is a possibility the driver suffered a medical episode while driving,” the news website reported. The bodies were recovered from the water by members of the Croatian Mountain Rescue Service from Gospić and transported to the Institute of Forensic Medicine in Rijeka for autopsy and identification. A criminal investigation is underway to determine the exact circumstances of the incident. Times of Malta is withholding the names of the victims until it is clear their families are informed.  More details to follow

content: Autopsy results of the two couples who died when their rental car plunged into the sea while on holiday in Croatia will be published on Monday.  Croatian sources told Times of Malta the Institute of Forensic Medicine in Rijeka, which is carrying out the autopsies, will have details of the results on Monday.  Jeremy Gambin, 68, and his wife Lorraine, 67, died alongside Kevin Bonnici, 67, and his wife Alexandra, 66. They were travelling together on the scenic Adriatic Coast when the car they were in veered off the road and into the sea on Thursday afternoon. The four were good friends and all lived in Swieqi.  Autopsy results could help shed light on the dynamics of the crash, with Croatian media having reported that the initial suspicion is that the person driving the vehicle may have become ill while driving, leading to the crash.   Jeremy Gambin was a basketball coach at Luxol and a former player who represented Malta at the 1987 Games of Small States of Europe in Monaco. He was also a PE Teacher at St Michael’s Foundation. He and his wife Lorraine, whose official name is Cynthia, had three children and several grandchildren.   Kevin Bonnici worked in the cab business and served as a company director of two separate Y-Plate fleet firms. He previously worked for Air Malta in the airline's finance, flight ops and engineering departments. He and his wife Alexandra had two children and various grandchildren.   Sources told Times of Malta that family members were travelling to Croatia on Saturday, and forensics will continue with the autopsy.  The accident happened at 4.20pm on Thursday, on the D8 state road near Bunica, just south of Senj. Police said the vehicle, travelling from Rijeka towards Senj, is believed to have lost control on a left-hand bend, veered right, struck two stone barriers and fell around 70 metres down a ravine before ending up in the water. Police officer Jasmin Mujaković from the Senj Police Station was among the first to arrive at the scene of the horrific accident, 24sata reported. He surfaced several times for air and then went down under the surface again, trying to find a way to reach the victims. A Croatian diver with over 30 years of experience has described Thursday’s fatal car accident that killed four Maltese tourists as the most difficult intervention of his career. Renato Huba said that while he had similar interventions before, he described the accident as “one of the most difficult”, he told Croatian newsroom. “I prepared myself for the worst situation, but that was not enough; this was much worse,” Huba said.

content: A crowdfunding campaign for a nurse left in a coma after a car crash that killed her unborn baby has raised more than €70,000 in two days. Tonamol Baby, 28, was five months pregnant when she was struck by a car while crossing the road to start her shift as a nurse at Mount Carmel Hospital on July 16. She lost her baby and has been in hospital ever since, while her 34-year-old husband Tom Jacob spends his days by her side, far from their home in Kerala, India. Tom turned to Times of Malta to share the couple’s story as he set up a crowdfunding campaign for an air ambulance to take her home.  The cost of the medical flight is around €20,000 and the hospital costs would be at least another €30,000.  Tom daily arrives at the neurosurgical ward at Mater Dei Hospital at 8am to sit by the bedside of his wife of three years, staying until he leaves for work at 6pm. He is employed as a sommelier with the db Group. He thanked everyone who contributed, including the db Group and “the db family”, the Healthmark team (Tona’s employers), the Kerala federations and Tonamol’s friends. “Words cannot fully express our gratitude. To each and every person who contributed, shared our story, or kept us in their thoughts, thank you from the bottom of our hearts. “Your kindness has given us hope and strength during one of the most difficult times of our lives. We assure you that all of you will be remembered in our prayers always. And we kindly ask you to continue keeping us in yours, more than anything, we need your prayers,” he said. On the day of the accident, Tom was having a cup of tea at the couple’s home in Buġibba when a friend called him with the news about his wife’s accident.  As she crossed the road, a car struck her right pelvic bone and, as she fell to the ground, her head hit a bollard. When Tom arrived at the hospital, he did not recognise his wife at first. Since then, however, he has seen an improvement and hopes she can recover at home in Kerala, surrounded by family. “I will be with her for a couple of months. Then, I hope, she will be okay and I will bring her back with me,” Tom said.

The families of the two couples killed in a horrific road crash in Croatia are preparing to bring their loved ones home on Friday. Jeremy and Lorraine Gambin and their best friends Kevin and Sandra Bonnici were killed last Thursday when their Land Rover Discovery plunged off a cliff and veered into the sea on the D8 state road near Bunica, just south of Senj. The funeral of the Gambin couple will be held on Saturday at Balluta church at 9.30am, the victims' son Justin Gambin told Times of Malta. The date of the funeral of the other couple is not yet known.  The four - aged between 66 and 68 - were lifelong friends who regularly holidayed abroad together. In a statement to Times of Malta, the Gambin family said: "Jeremy and Lorraine, humble and loved by all, lived life to the fullest. They left us doing what they loved most with their best friends." Drowning most likely cause of death Meanwhile, autopsy results reported by Croatian media say drowning was the most likely cause of death of the two couples, as only slight injuries were found on the bodies. All four are believed to have been wearing seatbelts. Forensic investigations are ongoing with experts unable to determine what caused the car to veer off the road. Initial reports in the Croatian media that the driver of the vehicle may have become ill while driving, thus leading to the crash, were not verified by the autopsy. The vehicle fell around 70 metres after veering off the road, before crashing into the sea to a depth of at least 11 metres. The investigation was conducted by forensic medicine specialists from the Institute of Forensic Medicine in Rijeka. Relatives of the four victims, including their children, laid flowers near the crash site in memory of their loved ones.  Justin Gambin said his father and Kevin Bonnici were “not only cousins but best friends who travelled all over the world together. They’ve driven around together for tens of thousands of kilometres”. Speaking to Times of Malta on Wednesday, he thanked the Croatian police in Senj for their assistance.  Questions on safety of road Meanwhile, questions have been raised about the safety of the D8 road, where certain stretches lack adequate barriers to prevent cars from plunging into the sea below. Jonathan Gambin, whose brother was among the victims, said that while stone bollards along the road “may appear protective, they were likely insufficient to prevent a vehicle from veering off the road”. He had expressed hope that further investigations into the accident would bring the victims’ relatives a measure of closure. It is not known whether the Senj Bora, the notorious strong northeasterly wind that blows along the Adriatic coast of Croatia, could have potentially contributed to the accident. There has also been some speculation in the Croatian media that an oncoming car could also have distracted the Maltese driver.  Croatian emergency divers described the operation to recover the car involved in the crash as one of the most difficult they had ever carried out, with experienced diver Renato Huba telling local media that while he had prepared for the worst, “this was much worse”. A member of the towing service praised a policeman who was among the first to arrive on the scene and who dived into the water in an attempt to open the door of the car damaged by the force of impact. "He tried everything he could. He jumped, dived, tried to open the door, but due to the extensive damage and the strong water pressure, it was simply not possible. He did his best," said Adrian Karamba, 24sata reported.

content: A motorcyclist was left with serious injuries after being involved in a traffic collision with a car in Żurrieq on Thursday morning. Preliminary investigations suggest a collision had occurred between the Piaggio Beverly motorbike driven by the injured party, a 61-year-old man from Mqabba, and a Toyota Aqua driven by a 67-year-old woman from Żurrieq. The incident occurred on Triq il-Belt Valletta at around 9.30am, police said. The motorcyclist was treated at the scene before being taken to Mater Dei Hospital, where his injuries were certified as serious. Magistrate Monica Borg Galea was informed of the incident and opened an inquiry into the case. Police investigations are still ongoing.

The Mayor of Għajnsielem on Friday called on the authorities to install speed cameras and traffic calming measures along Triq l-Imġarr after a four-vehicle collision left two people in hospital. One person suffered grievous injuries while another sustained light injuries in the accident, the latest in a string of “serious accidents” along that stretch of road which led mayor Kevin Cauchi to make his heartfelt appeal to the authorities. The accident, which happened around 9am, involved a Mitsubishi L200 driven by a 35-year old man from Xagħra and a Suzuki GSXR driven by a 43-year old man from Nadur. A 19-year old man also from Nadur was riding pillion. A Toyota Corolla driven by a 67-year old man from Qala and an Alfa Romeo driven by a 55-year old man from Munxar were also damaged in the collision. A medical team was called on site and an ambulance took the 43-year old man and the 19-year old youth to the Gozo General Hospital for treatment. Magistrate Brigitte Sultana appointed an inquiry as police investigations continued.  Writing in a social media post following the accident, Għajnsielem mayor Kevin Cauchi expressed his frustration at the lack of inaction following the latest accident on this stretch of road. “Another serious accident took place this morning on Triq l-Imġarr. The statistics speak for themselves yet still nothing is being done,” he said. He pointed out the local council has been appealing with the authority “for years” to install speed cameras, plastic bollards and other traffic calming measures along Triq l- Imġarr and other main roads.
